title: Is this hello world app of MS?
text: Amazing how childish the design of the interface is and how poor the functionality is. 5 out of 10 times the App doesn‚Äôt even receive a push from the client side and you wait for few seconds for it and then open the app to enter the code and by that time the client times out. Who at Microsoft designs these solutions? A high school drop out? Let alone the interface that has all the options of yes/cancel with no spacing between them and you often endup pressing cancel while trying to press yes. Have you seen any templates on the apple developer site? Probably copy one of those prompt sheets and you‚Äôll have better interface than this. A pathetic application and even more pathetic 2-step verification process overall. MS should do what they do best, buy someone else‚Äôs code/company that does this. As always your own code always is mediocre on your best day.

title: Terrible app from a corrupt entity.
text:
How anyone rates this as high as they do suggests willful ignorance or paid reviews.

The app doesn‚Äôt work well, alerts get missed and trusting a corrupt company with personal information is just plain dumb.

It is both abusive and absurd for a 2FA app to request the following:

Location
User Content
Contact Info
Identifiers
Usage Data
Diagnostics

All linked to the phone user.

Then it wants your passcode ‚Äî no. Other 2FA apps do not require such invasive information for access and use.

Microsoft, like Google, are tremendously wicked actors. Trusting them with such information is unwise to say the least.

title: Works great when it works
text:
Got a new phone. iCloud backup recovery didn‚Äôt restore this app fully. All good, but when I go to restore from Microsoft backup it tells me I‚Äôve tried to log in too many times and to try again tomorrow. Uhm‚Ä¶ first of all, no I haven‚Äôt and second, F you very much. And when I try to use my Microsoft security key (backup option for recovery) to gain access again, it tells me I have to wait 30 days!! 
Microsoft, security is one thing but when I, as the rightful owner, can‚Äôt even access my own accounts despite having all the right info, your essentially no better than a hacker locking me out of my accounts.

This is a sad excuse for online safety, a frustrating loophole of an ‚Äúauthenticator.‚Äù This app needs to be reevaluated.

title: Authenticator App needs Authenticator App to Authenticate the Authenticator App
text:
TL;DR: This app has a logic loop in the development that will lock you out of your work, school, and personal accounts including emails + Virtual Machines. There is nothing from Microsoft mentioning this horrible design and no solutions. If you want to download it, then good luck explaining to your boss why you can‚Äôt send or receive any emails, or join a Microsoft Teams Meeting. 

Read it and weep, this app is actually so bad. Firstly, if you get locked out of an email, virtual machine, whatever‚Ä¶ say you get a new phone and you want to sign into your outlook emails for example‚Ä¶ well, you need the Authenticator app to get into the email. 

Okay‚Ä¶ but you need the email to get into the Authenticator app. 

This is where the logic breaks. The email will ask you to type a code in your Authenticator app to log in to the email. But the Authenticator app will ask you to log into your email to use the Authenticator app. 

So you get stuck in a loop of the Authenticator app asking you to use the Authenticator app in order to use the Authenticator app to authenticate the email that is asking you to use the Authenticator app which then asks you to use the Authenticator app in order to use the Authenticator app to authenticate the email that is asking you to use the Authenticator app which then asks you to use the Authenticator app in order to use the Authenticator app to authenticate the email that is asking you to use the Authenticator app which then asks you to use the Authenticator app in order to use the Authenticator app to authenticate the email that is asking you to use the Authenticator app which then asks you to use the Authenticator app in order to use the Authenticator app to authenticate the email that is asking you to use the Authenticator app which then asks you to‚Ä¶ 

And there, that‚Äôs why the Microsoft Authenticator app makers are paycheck thieves. A fresh college grad would have immediately saw the faulty logic loop with some simple QA. 

Like‚Ä¶ did any of them ACTUALLY TEST the app? Why are there no options for a recovery email? No options for a 2-step verification code to be texted? How about a simple phone number to call someone about this? NOPE. 

Just more links and URLS that redirect to unhelpful and unrelated Microsoft support pages. 

Also, any helpful threads or ‚Äúsupport‚Äù from the Microsoft pages does not mention this loop. A whole lot of people are having this problem and it is not being addressed, the issue of this loop can barely be searched, it‚Äôs almost like it‚Äôs purposefully hidden while the company tries to fix their embarrassing mistake and pretend that everything is fine. 

Don‚Äôt download this app, it will just lock you out of everything work, school, and personal.

You have no idea how infuriating it is to go to approve sign in on the apple watch only to just be annoyed to do it directly from the phone‚Ä¶ its worse than worthless to have that notification show on the watch if you cant fully approve the sign-in, especially compared to Duo.
